body:
Sorry for the confusion. @pluskid   I am talking about better organizing them and hope to hear some suggestions from you. 

I think reasonably eliminating some of them might be a way to better organize the arguments. 

There are absolutely other ways, some of them coming out of my mind like: 
- Grouping the callbacks into one argument, with namedtuple. For example, when accessing callbacks, using `callback['batch_end_callback']` or `callback.batch_end_callback` and so.

@pluskid I have a question. The python code pass the last states into the initial states for each batch. So I think it's probably not ok to just pass zero blobs to init states. I am still working on evaluating the effect of this behaviour.

The state is reset after gradient update, and gradient update is done every batch by default.

Even if you want to copy over the states, that could be done, see for example the sampler example in Julia.
Solved, it was an error on my side, calling `mx.io.NDArrayIter` with different shapes.

Was too brief because I was one a phone. I looked at the python lstm example again. You are right, it seems the states are copied over during the whole epoch. The forward states are transferred even if the backward is cut by resetting the gradient. If you want to achieve this with high-level API, it is still possible by having the last states in the LSTM output, and copying that over in the data iteration. See [the Julia sampler](https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/blob/master/examples/char-lstm/sampler.jl#L58) for example.

But I think this is pretty much what you could achieve without extending a lot the current feedforward API. For more flexible LSTM/RNN, I think a separate model should be built.
Yes. I agree. Currently, building a separate model is a good(probably the best) idea. However, it cannot easily utilize the multi-GPU and distributed training benefit. Sigh. It's very hard to choose.

There is another not-so-cool thing related is that some parameters are passed when constructing the model, while others are passed when calling train. For example, `num_epoch` might better be an argument of `fit` instead of `__init__`. I'm not sure whether it is to keep consistency with the sklearn API or not. But I somehow gave up thinking of doing the refactoring because
- There are many parameters that one cannot avoid, so maybe re-organizing helps a bit, but not much
- Changing this kind of basic API one need to modify almost all the examples and unit-tests

But if you have time to think about it carefully, I tend to encourage you continue to make a proposal with details on how you want to refactor it and people could discuss.

I tried `git pull` and installing again, same issue. 

I then tried deleting the entire repo, re-cloning, re-building, and re-installing. Same issue. 

Are you using Python 2.7.6?

Hi, I would also like to help with this. 

Unfortunately, I'm not an expert in linking C libraries to other languages like Go, Python, and Java as you show above, so they aren't too illustrative of how one might go about using, say, a model trained in the Python bindings in a C++ context. 

Might there be other examples you could point to, or even perhaps some old commits that might show this? I'm afraid the documentation isn't too clear to me either, though I could certainly be reading them incorrectly.
yeah, `Python 2.7.6` with numpy `1.10.1`. @antinucleon @tqchen any idea about the error?

All calls from host languages to mxnet core are directed using the C API here:https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/c_api.h Please let us know if you have further questions.
Likely because some source of your tensor's shape was not intialized?

This question is a bit without context.

This should in general be true, unless layer1 is also connected to other layer, and the gradient will be summed up.  If it was not the case on your side, maybe consider post an minimum example to reproduce the problem

layer1 has pre layer, and only one post layer.
for example:
I set the values of in_grad of layer2 all 1s. and then the out_grad of layer1 only have several 1s, others are 0s.
this is really strange.
BTW, layer2 is the loss layer.
BTW2, layer2 has serveral label parameters, not only one.

Yes, this is strange if it is what you described, it could be  memory overflow problem that faied to assign some of in_grad. 

Or you forget to declare dependency to out_grad, in such case the out_grad will simply be invalid in backward
I don't know how to rebase. I haven't done this before.
actually, the layer1 is cov layer, and the layer2 is my self-defined loss layer. and the loss layer do not need to backdepend of the out_grad.

maybe it is he memory overflow problem of in_grad of layer2.
but I print the values of in_grad after I set its value. and it is normal.
http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#git-workflow-howtos
I found the in_grad value is affected by in_data.
in_data is just like a mask of in_grad.
check the inplace option, if you set that, but the operation you performed cannot be done in inplace manner
I have no inplace functions.
zero values of in_data should has no correspond values of in_grad. maybe its the reason.
I have little evidence on what happened on your side then. Maybe you can do some unit tests on the operators to see if the behavior is correct.

does mshadow or mxnet process the following automatically?
`zero values of in_data should has no correspond values of in_grad`
I don't understand your question
i am confused a little also....

I see what you mean, you cannot assume mutating the input of in_data will change the state of previous layer. Each operator should act in an independent way, by only mutating the outputs(out_data in forward and in_grad in backward).

Otherwise the behavior is undefined. Because the memory allocation algorithm will take advantage of such restriction and re-uses some of the memory

how do you explain this situation?
the tdata_in really acts like a mask of tgrad_in of this layer and out_grad of pre-layer.
this is unreasonable.

The restriction is you can only change in_grad in backward and out_data in forward, the operator will need to obey this restriction. Because the gradient is all the previous operator need to backprop the gradient to input(maybe together with some context like in_data, out_data)
I don't think the in_data has any relationship with in_grad also, but the experiment data shows not.
You cannot change content of in_data in Backward Function.
just experiment, I want know what's wrong between the in_grad and out_grad.

I will do more experiments to find the reason.
Do you have any other better suggestion?
Good luck on finding the cause. But please do not assume you can change content of in_data in backward
OK, I will not do it.

one is responsible for one data source.

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/617#issuecomment-157644431.

In this case you need to specify multiple mx.sym.Variable. For example

``` python
data1 = mx.symbol.Variable('data1')
fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data1, name='fc1', num_hidden=128)
data2 = mx.symbol.Variable('data2')
fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data2, name='fc2', num_hidden=128)
concat = mx.symbol.Concat(*[data1, data2])
fc3 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=concat, name='fc3', num_hiddent=128)
softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, name='softmax')

```

Thanks for suggestion! Indeed it is very easy to implement new optimization algorithm in MXNet eg, Adam in [Julia](https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/blob/master/src/optimizers/adam.jl). We may start to word on it after ICLR deadline. Also any contribution to make new optimizers to `python/mxnet/optimizer.py` is more than welcome :)

Hi, thanks for the suggestion. Actually we have experimented with several advanced optimization methods in previous project cxxnet, however the difference between sgd is minor at least in the case of CNN. Anyway, we could implement some of them as mentioned by @antinucleon
@jermainewang How do you use a callback to adjust the model parameters?  Could you give a short example `epoch_end_callback` that adjusts the learning rate?
I would also like to try out some different optimizers in the R package =D
Solved , It's my problem.:smile:

I don't think it can work when any tensor's shape was not initialized. isn't it?
tensor must have shape, otherwise it cannot exist.

So I am not sure that `kaiming` is the correct name. I would prefer specifying the regularization as `avg` = (fan_in + fan_out) / 2; in = fan_in; out = fan_out and the the difference between `xavier` and `kaiming` is just the magnitude.

Also see https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/1946 and https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/1883 for some more discussion and http://arxiv.org/abs/1312.6120v3 for the paper where `kaiming` was first proposed the `A` in `MSRA`.

Also note they Caffe calculates fan_in and fan_out differently from us:

```
You should make sure the input blob has shape (num, a, b, c) where a * b * c = fan_in and num * b * c  = fan_out. 
```
from #601

At least I think use fan_out directly is useless and will make training fail because it is too large. I prefer manual adjust magnitude instead of stick on some magic formula. eg, if you check keras there will be a different define of these stuff formula.

Just think about this for a little while.

What about saving the model as a json string in Rdata. When loading, we parse the json string.

This can be done by adding two helper functions.
Hi. thanks for the PR. Could you please update the README as well?

Hi, guys,
    thanks for pointing out how to write a multi source input network. Moreover, how can we write the training command?
    Currently, I am following the CIFAR 100 example. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/cifar-100.ipynb
    How can we feed multi source input to the network when calling model.fit to train the network?
You are also more than welcomed to implement your own and contribute back to mxnet.

My viewpoint is mostly around prediction using the model object so I'll focus on how we could export the prediction function. I can think of two options:
- some stand-alone `C` programs like `C5.0` drop the model parameters (splits and variables in that case) into a text file that is then parsed at prediction time by separate code. You could have a defined format to export the weights and biases and some `R` or  `C++` code could parse it for making predictions. This is basically what @thirdwing is proposing (I think)
- it wouldn't be difficult, even for large networks, to have your code write an actual `R` function for the prediction equation (including the weight and bias values to full precision). It is kludgy but is the most portable way of accomplishing the goal.

Thanks,

Max

If you could provide some docs on writing new optimizers, I'll try my hand at porting adagrad from keras:
https://github.com/fchollet/keras/blob/a19c9ecfbd99a0fc60c476fb8a0fbd3284a9d620/keras/optimizers.py#L116

Hi,

Here is a simple example on how to do it in callback way. I use the [cifar10](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/cifar10) example as the code base.

What you need to do is to capture the optimizer in a function closure:

``` python
import mxnet.optimizer as opt
def test_cifar():
  logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
  gpus = [mx.gpu(i) for i in range(num_gpus)]
  sgd_opt = opt.SGD(learning_rate=0.005, momentum=0.9, wd=0.0001, rescale_grad=(1.0/batch_size))
  model = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=gpus, symbol=softmax, num_epoch=num_epoch,
              optimizer=sgd_opt, initializer=mx.init.Uniform(0.07))
  def lr_callback(param):
    if param.nbatch % 10 == 0:
      sgd_opt.lr /= 10 # decrease learning rate by a factor of 10 every 10 batches
    print 'nbatch:%d, learning rate:%f' % (param.nbatch, sgd_opt.lr)

  model.fit(X=train_dataiter, eval_data=test_dataiter, batch_end_callback=lr_callback)
```

On my machine, it outputs something like followings:

```
[12:58:18] src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc:212: ImageRecordIOParser: data/cifar/train.rec, use 1 threads for decoding..

```

Hope this helps,

-Minjie

It is never hard to explicit save something that is serializable in Rdata form.  We have ways to save graph to json string, and ndarrays(parameters) to raw type in R. 

Problem is on eagerly saving things to object everytime an object is generated. Which could be costly for object such as array(means need to dump things from GPU to CPU everytime an operation is calculated).
- This eager saving approach may not be too bad for model object, since model is rather costly to build.
- It will also work if the upper level tool calling mx provide some explicit wrapper that calls the save.to.robject, load.from.robject.

@shuokay, the correct way to use `lr_scheduler` is to pass it to `mx.model.FeedForward`:
In lenet.py

```
model = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=dev, symbol=lenet, num_epoch=20,  
  learning_rate=0.05, momentum=0.9, wd=0.00001, 
  lr_scheduler=mx.misc.FactorScheduler(step=5))
```

Interestingly, there is a bug in optimizer that is fixed in #622, so it should work now.

Thank you for your question!

Minjie

Hi,

We are considering this as well! The thing is that for company like AMD, they are actually developing environments that is compatible with CUDA in the future: http://www.anandtech.com/show/9792/amd-sc15-boltzmann-initiative-announced-c-and-cuda-compilers-for-amd-gpus. So we are still deciding whether we are going to put our limited human resources into supporint OpenCL. If you are interested, you are more than welcome to help us enhance the project in this direction.

Thank you,
Minjie

@zachmayer 

See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/optimizer.R#L4 as an example.

The training command `fit` is the same. You just need to specify a multi input network and data iterator. 

Note that the default data iterator currently does not support multi source input.  You need to hack a little of [NDArrayIter](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/io.py#L126) to build your own data iterator.

Hi, thanks for your advice! This will indeed help a lot to avoid bugs in copy/paste codes. Would you like to offer a hand on this? :)

Minjie

Maybe we can collaborate on extending MXnet with OpenCL support. we have
Opencl caffe open sourced, I guess we can reuse the core kernels?

thanks!

Ha, it's great to hear voice from AMD people here :p. I heard that the problem of integrating OpenCL is mainly due to its support for template which is widely used in mshadow. @tqchen may know more details about this.

Minjie
you can try my Adam pull request https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/623
if the gpus are identical, you can fix a batch size of each gpu, say 48, then `batch_size = 48 * num_gpus_on_this_machine.`. otherwise please refer to PR #566

great PR, thanks!

beside naiyan's comment, could you please acknowledge that we used caffe's .proto in tools/cafe_converter/readme.md. also do we still need google protobuf? if yes, we probably remove the auto generated pb.py file and provide a makefile to generate it instead. since the file varies for different protobuf version.

@gujunli it's very nice to see you here, (we met at icml beijing last year). we are definitely interested on opencl, and hope to support it asap. but the current issue is that we used C++ template while opencl doesn't support it, see https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/issues/71

template is an issue. On AMD devices we have special keyword to support, no
problem. The problem is the same key word does not work on NV GPUs. we are
also figuring out a general solution. I would like to hear your thoughts on
this.@limu @minjie

junli

Junli Gu--谷俊丽

nvidia gpu should be fine with cuda. our main motivation to support opencl is for amd gpus and other devices, such as fpga. for example, altera also contacted us to make mxnet run on their devices.

This won't pose a problem as long as AMD's version of compiler support somewhat similar thing as nvcc does, i.e. template programming and allow integration of host and device code. 

What can be done is to have something like  tensor_gpu-inl.amd.cc to specialize for AMD's version of keyword. As long as the extra keyword is minimum and the compiler can be detected by marco, it should be fine.
Doesn't ndarray iter already support multiple input?
Let me write `mx.model.save.Rdata`/`mx.model.load.Rdata` and do some benchmarking.

Thanks a lot for the contribution.
Could you fix the lint errors?
You can check locally with "make lint"

Also, 
1) please remove "import mxnet as mx" and import only what you need like
"from .ndarray import sqr, sqrt"

2) Are you sure it's weight[:] += step_grad, not weight[:] -= step_grad?

It would be nice to be able to target FPGAs and OpenCL would allow that to be done much more easily through the Altera tool chain. 

Also: I'm not sure I understand the templates issue, isn't there a C API that could be used to get around that?
I'll also add that OpenCL would allow targetting Intel Integrated Graphics which is pretty common on a lot of laptops as well as desktops these days.
